title: United States Coast Guard Officer Personnel Management

enrichment.summary: This executive order delegates the President's authority over the appointment, promotion, separation, and retirement of commissioned officers in the United States Coast Guard to the Secretary of Homeland Security. It also clarifies authority during times when the Coast Guard operates as part of the Navy and outlines procedures during war or national emergencies.
potential_concerns: Delegating presidential appointment and promotion authority to the Secretary of Homeland Security may raise concerns about maintaining military-readiness and proper checks on Coast Guard officer management, affecting active-duty personnel.

During war or national emergencies, broad authority to suspend certain laws and promote officers without presidential approval could lead to inconsistent or politicized personnel decisions impacting military-personnel-active-duty and reserves.

The shift in authority when the Coast Guard operates as part of the Navy transfers decision-making to the Secretary of Defense, which could create coordination challenges or delays affecting Coast Guard officersâ€™ career progression.

Non-transparent decision-making processes under delegated authority may reduce oversight and perceived fairness in promotions and separations, potentially undermining morale among active-duty Coast Guard members.
